text:
that's ok - Understandably you've got a lot going on, but yeah, it's really nice to be working at something you enjoy doing, and that made a huge difference to me after school. I was never very good at studying the things i found it hard to engage with. - that's kind of why I was keen to say there's no point in ruining the fun by making it into a chore at the moment, you've got plenty of time to causally just mess around with things.

- I went to the university of Hertfordshire and studied a BA in visual effects, which i would thoroughly recommend. Its frequently listed in the top 3 courses in the UK for animation and VFX. here's their student reel - <https://vimeo.com/264905924> here's their facebook <https://www.facebook.com/uhanimation/>, the other two courses that rank are normally Bournemouth university, which is superb for the more technical fx-y side, and the escape course, which i hear is great, but also very very pricey.
- I didn't do an internship, but it was certainly encouraged. I think it's a really useful thing to see how a studio works, and interesting to see how teams work. A lot of my course mates had mixed experiences with internships, and i think it really comes down to where you end up on placement. It's important to be somewhere that's not super stressed and busy, that can make time to help you out and answer questions.
- I'd started messing around with photoshop in school, probably age 14/15 doing angsty/angry teenage art. Good times! I had an embarrassing deviantart account full of angsty photoshop work, which i used to do after school. I also used to make little vfx tests and "edgy" videos, some of them are probably on my vimeo.

attachments.title: UH Animation Showreel 2018
attachments.text:
University of Hertfordshire Digital Animation Showreel 2018.
Work created by the BA Games Art, VFX, 2D and 3D Animation pathways.

(Click below to findout official information)

BA (Hons) 2D Digital Animation | 

BA (Hons) Games Art | 

BA (Hons) 3D Digital Animation | 

BA (Hons) Visual Effects for Film and Television | 

The digital animation programme equips students with the high level of skills needed to succeed in today's animation industry. It emphasises creativity, character design, story, cinematography, VFX and compositing 3D and Games Art; all channelled through the advanced software skills needed to achieve inventive and engaging animation. These programmes develop digital modelling and character animation skills, virtual lighting and virtual camera work, exposing students to the latest professional 3D animation practices. The students create short animated final films or fully playable games levels. Employment opportunities include computer animation companies, work with games, TV and film special effects companies. Our graduated students have worked and freelanced with some of the world's best known production and post production houses.

Contacts 
Martin Bowman - 
Dan Goodbrey - 

Music Title "Memory" by Creo

attachments.text: Ive seen a load of different peoples bullet time videos, so I thought I would make my own.

attachments.title: Cello Sonata
attachments.text:
A music video produced for my college course. I'm not really sure where this idea came from, though my guess is I thought of it when I was almost asleep or almost awake.

Software:

3ds max 8 
Adobe premier cs3
Camstudio
Goldwave
Adobe Photoshop cs3

attachments.title: Bin fire!
attachments.text:
Recently got the fumefx plugin for 3ds max, so I was messing about with it.

Made with:

3ds max 8
Boujou 4
Fumefx
premier

I also had to dismantle 2 novelty disco lights and place one in the bin... There's some pretty primitive stuff going on
